property.name: hadoop.hdfs.configuration.version
property.description: version of this configuration file

property.name: dfs.namenode.logging.level
property.description: The logging level for dfs namenode. Other values are "dir" (trace namespace mutations), "block" (trace block under/over replications and block creations/deletions), or "all".

property.name: dfs.namenode.rpc-address
property.description: RPC address that handles all clients requests. In the case of HA/Federation where multiple namenodes exist, the name service id is added to the name e.g. dfs.namenode.rpc-address.ns1 dfs.namenode.rpc-address.EXAMPLENAMESERVICE The value of this property will take the form of hdfs://nn-host1:rpc-port.

property.name: dfs.namenode.servicerpc-address
property.description: RPC address for HDFS Services communication. BackupNode, Datanodes and all other services should be connecting to this address if it is configured. In the case of HA/Federation where multiple namenodes exist, the name service id is added to the name e.g. dfs.namenode.servicerpc-address.ns1 dfs.namenode.rpc-address.EXAMPLENAMESERVICE The value of this property will take the form of hdfs://nn-host1:rpc-port. If the value of this property is unset the value of dfs.namenode.rpc-address will be used as the default.

property.name: dfs.namenode.secondary.http-address
property.description: The secondary namenode http server address and port.

property.name: dfs.datanode.address
property.description: The datanode server address and port for data transfer.

property.name: dfs.datanode.http.address
property.description: The datanode http server address and port.

property.name: dfs.datanode.ipc.address
property.description: The datanode ipc server address and port.

property.name: dfs.datanode.handler.count
property.description: The number of server threads for the datanode.

property.name: dfs.namenode.http-address
property.description: The address and the base port where the dfs namenode web ui will listen on.

property.name: dfs.https.enable
property.description: Decide if HTTPS(SSL) is supported on HDFS

property.name: dfs.client.https.need-auth
property.description: Whether SSL client certificate authentication is required

property.name: dfs.https.server.keystore.resource
property.description: Resource file from which ssl server keystore information will be extracted

property.name: dfs.client.https.keystore.resource
property.description: Resource file from which ssl client keystore information will be extracted

property.name: dfs.datanode.https.address
property.description: The datanode secure http server address and port.

property.name: dfs.namenode.https-address
property.description: The namenode secure http server address and port.

property.name: dfs.datanode.dns.interface
property.description: The name of the Network Interface from which a data node should report its IP address.

property.name: dfs.datanode.dns.nameserver
property.description: The host name or IP address of the name server (DNS) which a DataNode should use to determine the host name used by the NameNode for communication and display purposes.

property.name: dfs.namenode.backup.address
property.description: The backup node server address and port. If the port is 0 then the server will start on a free port.

property.name: dfs.namenode.backup.http-address
property.description: The backup node http server address and port. If the port is 0 then the server will start on a free port.

property.name: dfs.namenode.replication.considerLoad
property.description: Decide if chooseTarget considers the target's load or not

property.name: dfs.default.chunk.view.size
property.description: The number of bytes to view for a file on the browser.

property.name: dfs.datanode.du.reserved
property.description: Reserved space in bytes per volume. Always leave this much space free for non dfs use.

property.name: dfs.namenode.name.dir
property.description: Determines where on the local filesystem the DFS name node should store the name table(fsimage). If this is a comma-delimited list of directories then the name table is replicated in all of the directories, for redundancy.

property.name: dfs.namenode.name.dir.restore
property.description: Set to true to enable NameNode to attempt recovering a previously failed dfs.namenode.name.dir. When enabled, a recovery of any failed directory is attempted during checkpoint.

property.name: dfs.namenode.fs-limits.max-component-length
property.description: Defines the maximum number of characters in each component of a path. A value of 0 will disable the check.

property.name: dfs.namenode.fs-limits.max-directory-items
property.description: Defines the maximum number of items that a directory may contain. A value of 0 will disable the check.

property.name: dfs.namenode.edits.dir
property.description: Determines where on the local filesystem the DFS name node should store the transaction (edits) file. If this is a comma-delimited list of directories then the transaction file is replicated in all of the directories, for redundancy. Default value is same as dfs.namenode.name.dir

property.name: dfs.namenode.shared.edits.dir
property.description: A directory on shared storage between the multiple namenodes in an HA cluster. This directory will be written by the active and read by the standby in order to keep the namespaces synchronized. This directory does not need to be listed in dfs.namenode.edits.dir above. It should be left empty in a non-HA cluster.

property.name: dfs.permissions.enabled
property.description: If "true", enable permission checking in HDFS. If "false", permission checking is turned off, but all other behavior is unchanged. Switching from one parameter value to the other does not change the mode, owner or group of files or directories.

property.name: dfs.permissions.superusergroup
property.description: The name of the group of super-users.

property.name: dfs.block.access.token.enable
property.description: If "true", access tokens are used as capabilities for accessing datanodes. If "false", no access tokens are checked on accessing datanodes.

property.name: dfs.block.access.key.update.interval
property.description: Interval in minutes at which namenode updates its access keys.

property.name: dfs.block.access.token.lifetime
property.description: The lifetime of access tokens in minutes.

property.name: dfs.datanode.data.dir
property.description: Determines where on the local filesystem an DFS data node should store its blocks. If this is a comma-delimited list of directories, then data will be stored in all named directories, typically on different devices. Directories that do not exist are ignored.

property.name: dfs.datanode.data.dir.perm
property.description: Permissions for the directories on on the local filesystem where the DFS data node store its blocks. The permissions can either be octal or symbolic.

property.name: dfs.replication
property.description: Default block replication. The actual number of replications can be specified when the file is created. The default is used if replication is not specified in create time.

property.name: dfs.replication.max
property.description: Maximal block replication.

property.name: dfs.namenode.replication.min
property.description: Minimal block replication.

property.name: dfs.blocksize
property.description: The default block size for new files, in bytes. You can use the following suffix (case insensitive): k(kilo), m(mega), g(giga), t(tera), p(peta), e(exa) to specify the size (such as 128k, 512m, 1g, etc.), Or provide complete size in bytes (such as 134217728 for 128 MB).

property.name: dfs.client.block.write.retries
property.description: The number of retries for writing blocks to the data nodes, before we signal failure to the application.

property.name: dfs.client.block.write.replace-datanode-on-failure.enable
property.description:
If there is a datanode/network failure in the write pipeline, DFSClient will try to remove the failed datanode from the pipeline and then continue writing with the remaining datanodes. As a result, the number of datanodes in the pipeline is decreased. The feature is to add new datanodes to the pipeline.
This is a site-wide property to enable/disable the feature.
When the cluster size is extremely small, e.g. 3 nodes or less, cluster administrators may want to set the policy to NEVER in the default configuration file or disable this feature. Otherwise, users may experience an unusually high rate of pipeline failures since it is impossible to find new datanodes for replacement.
See also dfs.client.block.write.replace-datanode-on-failure.policy

property.name: dfs.client.block.write.replace-datanode-on-failure.policy
property.description:
This property is used only if the value of dfs.client.block.write.replace-datanode-on-failure.enable is true.
ALWAYS: always add a new datanode when an existing datanode is removed.
NEVER: never add a new datanode.
DEFAULT: Let r be the replication number. Let n be the number of existing datanodes. Add a new datanode only if r is greater than or equal to 3 and either (1) floor(r/2) is greater than or equal to n; or (2) r is greater than n and the block is hflushed/appended.

property.name: dfs.blockreport.intervalMsec
property.description: Determines block reporting interval in milliseconds.

property.name: dfs.blockreport.initialDelay
property.description: Delay for first block report in seconds.

property.name: dfs.datanode.directoryscan.interval
property.description: Interval in seconds for Datanode to scan data directories and reconcile the difference between blocks in memory and on the disk.

property.name: dfs.datanode.directoryscan.threads
property.description: How many threads should the threadpool used to compile reports for volumes in parallel have.

property.name: dfs.heartbeat.interval
property.description: Determines datanode heartbeat interval in seconds.

property.name: dfs.namenode.handler.count
property.description: The number of server threads for the namenode.

property.name: dfs.namenode.safemode.threshold-pct
property.description: Specifies the percentage of blocks that should satisfy the minimal replication requirement defined by dfs.namenode.replication.min. Values less than or equal to 0 mean not to wait for any particular percentage of blocks before exiting safemode. Values greater than 1 will make safe mode permanent.

property.name: dfs.namenode.safemode.min.datanodes
property.description: Specifies the number of datanodes that must be considered alive before the name node exits safemode. Values less than or equal to 0 mean not to take the number of live datanodes into account when deciding whether to remain in safe mode during startup. Values greater than the number of datanodes in the cluster will make safe mode permanent.

property.name: dfs.namenode.safemode.extension
property.description: Determines extension of safe mode in milliseconds after the threshold level is reached.

property.name: dfs.datanode.balance.bandwidthPerSec
property.description: Specifies the maximum amount of bandwidth that each datanode can utilize for the balancing purpose in term of the number of bytes per second.

property.name: dfs.hosts
property.description: Names a file that contains a list of hosts that are permitted to connect to the namenode. The full pathname of the file must be specified. If the value is empty, all hosts are permitted.

property.name: dfs.hosts.exclude
property.description: Names a file that contains a list of hosts that are not permitted to connect to the namenode. The full pathname of the file must be specified. If the value is empty, no hosts are excluded.

property.name: dfs.namenode.max.objects
property.description: The maximum number of files, directories and blocks dfs supports. A value of zero indicates no limit to the number of objects that dfs supports.

property.name: dfs.namenode.decommission.interval
property.description: Namenode periodicity in seconds to check if decommission is complete.

property.name: dfs.namenode.decommission.nodes.per.interval
property.description: The number of nodes namenode checks if decommission is complete in each dfs.namenode.decommission.interval.

property.name: dfs.namenode.replication.interval
property.description: The periodicity in seconds with which the namenode computes repliaction work for datanodes.

property.name: dfs.namenode.accesstime.precision
property.description: The access time for HDFS file is precise upto this value. The default value is 1 hour. Setting a value of 0 disables access times for HDFS.

property.name: dfs.datanode.plugins
property.description: Comma-separated list of datanode plug-ins to be activated.

property.name: dfs.namenode.plugins
property.description: Comma-separated list of namenode plug-ins to be activated.

property.name: dfs.stream-buffer-size
property.description: The size of buffer to stream files. The size of this buffer should probably be a multiple of hardware page size (4096 on Intel x86), and it determines how much data is buffered during read and write operations.

property.name: dfs.bytes-per-checksum
property.description: The number of bytes per checksum. Must not be larger than dfs.stream-buffer-size

property.name: dfs.client-write-packet-size
property.description: Packet size for clients to write

property.name: dfs.namenode.checkpoint.dir
property.description: Determines where on the local filesystem the DFS secondary name node should store the temporary images to merge. If this is a comma-delimited list of directories then the image is replicated in all of the directories for redundancy.

property.name: dfs.namenode.checkpoint.edits.dir
property.description: Determines where on the local filesystem the DFS secondary name node should store the temporary edits to merge. If this is a comma-delimited list of directoires then teh edits is replicated in all of the directoires for redundancy. Default value is same as dfs.namenode.checkpoint.dir

property.name: dfs.namenode.checkpoint.period
property.description: The number of seconds between two periodic checkpoints.

property.name: dfs.namenode.checkpoint.txns
property.description: The Secondary NameNode or CheckpointNode will create a checkpoint of the namespace every 'dfs.namenode.checkpoint.txns' transactions, regardless of whether 'dfs.namenode.checkpoint.period' has expired.

property.name: dfs.namenode.checkpoint.check.period
property.description: The SecondaryNameNode and CheckpointNode will poll the NameNode every 'dfs.namenode.checkpoint.check.period' seconds to query the number of uncheckpointed transactions.

property.name: dfs.namenode.num.checkpoints.retained
property.description: The number of image checkpoint files that will be retained by the NameNode and Secondary NameNode in their storage directories. All edit logs necessary to recover an up-to-date namespace from the oldest retained checkpoint will also be retained.

property.name: dfs.namenode.num.extra.edits.retained
property.description:
The number of extra transactions which should be retained beyond what is minimally necessary for a NN restart. This can be useful for audit purposes or for an HA setup where a remote Standby Node may have been offline for some time and need to have a longer backlog of retained edits in order to start again. Typically each edit is on the order of a few hundred bytes, so the default of 1 million edits should be on the order of hundreds of MBs or low GBs.
NOTE: Fewer extra edits may be retained than value specified for this setting if doing so would mean that more segments would be retained than the number configured by dfs.namenode.max.extra.edits.segments.retained.

property.name: dfs.namenode.max.extra.edits.segments.retained
property.description: The maximum number of extra edit log segments which should be retained beyond what is minimally necessary for a NN restart. When used in conjunction with dfs.namenode.num.extra.edits.retained, this configuration property serves to cap the number of extra edits files to a reasonable value.

property.name: dfs.namenode.delegation.key.update-interval
property.description: The update interval for master key for delegation tokens in the namenode in milliseconds.

property.name: dfs.namenode.delegation.token.max-lifetime
property.description: The maximum lifetime in milliseconds for which a delegation token is valid.

property.name: dfs.namenode.delegation.token.renew-interval
property.description: The renewal interval for delegation token in milliseconds.

property.name: dfs.datanode.failed.volumes.tolerated
property.description: The number of volumes that are allowed to fail before a datanode stops offering service. By default any volume failure will cause a datanode to shutdown.

property.name: dfs.image.compress
property.description: Should the dfs image be compressed?

property.name: dfs.image.compression.codec
property.description: If the dfs image is compressed, how should they be compressed? This has to be a codec defined in io.compression.codecs.

property.name: dfs.image.transfer.bandwidthPerSec
property.description: Specifies the maximum amount of bandwidth that can be utilized for image transfer in term of the number of bytes per second. A default value of 0 indicates that throttling is disabled.

property.name: dfs.namenode.support.allow.format
property.description: Does HDFS namenode allow itself to be formatted? You may consider setting this to false for any production cluster, to avoid any possibility of formatting a running DFS.

property.name: dfs.datanode.max.transfer.threads
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of threads to use for transferring data in and out of the DN.

property.name: dfs.datanode.readahead.bytes
property.description:
While reading block files, if the Hadoop native libraries are available, the datanode can use the posix_fadvise system call to explicitly page data into the operating system buffer cache ahead of the current reader's position. This can improve performance especially when disks are highly contended.
This configuration specifies the number of bytes ahead of the current read position which the datanode will attempt to read ahead. This feature may be disabled by configuring this property to 0.
If the native libraries are not available, this configuration has no effect.

property.name: dfs.datanode.drop.cache.behind.reads
property.description:
In some workloads, the data read from HDFS is known to be significantly large enough that it is unlikely to be useful to cache it in the operating system buffer cache. In this case, the DataNode may be configured to automatically purge all data from the buffer cache after it is delivered to the client. This behavior is automatically disabled for workloads which read only short sections of a block (e.g HBase random-IO workloads).
This may improve performance for some workloads by freeing buffer cache spage usage for more cacheable data.
If the Hadoop native libraries are not available, this configuration has no effect.

property.name: dfs.datanode.drop.cache.behind.writes
property.description:
In some workloads, the data written to HDFS is known to be significantly large enough that it is unlikely to be useful to cache it in the operating system buffer cache. In this case, the DataNode may be configured to automatically purge all data from the buffer cache after it is written to disk.
This may improve performance for some workloads by freeing buffer cache spage usage for more cacheable data.
If the Hadoop native libraries are not available, this configuration has no effect.

property.name: dfs.datanode.sync.behind.writes
property.description:
If this configuration is enabled, the datanode will instruct the operating system to enqueue all written data to the disk immediately after it is written. This differs from the usual OS policy which may wait for up to 30 seconds before triggering writeback.
This may improve performance for some workloads by smoothing the IO profile for data written to disk.
If the Hadoop native libraries are not available, this configuration has no effect.

property.name: dfs.client.failover.max.attempts
property.description: Expert only. The number of client failover attempts that should be made before the failover is considered failed.

property.name: dfs.client.failover.sleep.base.millis
property.description: Expert only. The time to wait, in milliseconds, between failover attempts increases exponentially as a function of the number of attempts made so far, with a random factor of +/- 50%. This option specifies the base value used in the failover calculation. The first failover will retry immediately. The 2nd failover attempt will delay at least dfs.client.failover.sleep.base.millis milliseconds. And so on.

property.name: dfs.client.failover.sleep.max.millis
property.description: Expert only. The time to wait, in milliseconds, between failover attempts increases exponentially as a function of the number of attempts made so far, with a random factor of +/- 50%. This option specifies the maximum value to wait between failovers. Specifically, the time between two failover attempts will not exceed +/- 50% of dfs.client.failover.sleep.max.millis milliseconds.

property.name: dfs.client.failover.connection.retries
property.description: Expert only. Indicates the number of retries a failover IPC client will make to establish a server connection.

property.name: dfs.client.failover.connection.retries.on.timeouts
property.description: Expert only. The number of retry attempts a failover IPC client will make on socket timeout when establishing a server connection.

property.name: dfs.nameservices
property.description: Comma-separated list of nameservices.

property.name: dfs.nameservice.id
property.description: The ID of this nameservice. If the nameservice ID is not configured or more than one nameservice is configured for dfs.nameservices it is determined automatically by matching the local node's address with the configured address.

property.name: dfs.ha.namenodes.EXAMPLENAMESERVICE
property.description: The prefix for a given nameservice, contains a comma-separated list of namenodes for a given nameservice (eg EXAMPLENAMESERVICE).

property.name: dfs.ha.namenode.id
property.description: The ID of this namenode. If the namenode ID is not configured it is determined automatically by matching the local node's address with the configured address.

property.name: dfs.ha.log-roll.period
property.description: How often, in seconds, the StandbyNode should ask the active to roll edit logs. Since the StandbyNode only reads from finalized log segments, the StandbyNode will only be as up-to-date as how often the logs are rolled. Note that failover triggers a log roll so the StandbyNode will be up to date before it becomes active.

property.name: dfs.ha.tail-edits.period
property.description: How often, in seconds, the StandbyNode should check for new finalized log segments in the shared edits log.

property.name: dfs.ha.automatic-failover.enabled
property.description: Whether automatic failover is enabled. See the HDFS High Availability documentation for details on automatic HA configuration.

property.name: dfs.support.append
property.description: Does HDFS allow appends to files?

property.name: dfs.client.use.datanode.hostname
property.description: Whether clients should use datanode hostnames when connecting to datanodes.

property.name: dfs.datanode.use.datanode.hostname
property.description: Whether datanodes should use datanode hostnames when connecting to other datanodes for data transfer.

property.name: dfs.client.local.interfaces
property.description: A comma separated list of network interface names to use for data transfer between the client and datanodes. When creating a connection to read from or write to a datanode, the client chooses one of the specified interfaces at random and binds its socket to the IP of that interface. Individual names may be specified as either an interface name (eg "eth0"), a subinterface name (eg "eth0:0"), or an IP address (which may be specified using CIDR notation to match a range of IPs).

property.name: dfs.namenode.avoid.read.stale.datanode
property.description: Indicate whether or not to avoid reading from "stale" datanodes whose heartbeat messages have not been received by the namenode for more than a specified time interval. Stale datanodes will be moved to the end of the node list returned for reading. See dfs.namenode.avoid.write.stale.datanode for a similar setting for writes.

property.name: dfs.namenode.avoid.write.stale.datanode
property.description: Indicate whether or not to avoid writing to "stale" datanodes whose heartbeat messages have not been received by the namenode for more than a specified time interval. Writes will avoid using stale datanodes unless more than a configured ratio (dfs.namenode.write.stale.datanode.ratio) of datanodes are marked as stale. See dfs.namenode.avoid.read.stale.datanode for a similar setting for reads.

property.name: dfs.namenode.stale.datanode.interval
property.description: Default time interval for marking a datanode as "stale", i.e., if the namenode has not received heartbeat msg from a datanode for more than this time interval, the datanode will be marked and treated as "stale" by default. The stale interval cannot be too small since otherwise this may cause too frequent change of stale states. We thus set a minimum stale interval value (the default value is 3 times of heartbeat interval) and guarantee that the stale interval cannot be less than the minimum value.

property.name: dfs.namenode.write.stale.datanode.ratio
property.description: When the ratio of number stale datanodes to total datanodes marked is greater than this ratio, stop avoiding writing to stale nodes so as to prevent causing hotspots.

property.name: dfs.namenode.invalidate.work.pct.per.iteration
property.description: *Note*: Advanced property. Change with caution. This determines the percentage amount of block invalidations (deletes) to do over a single DN heartbeat deletion command. The final deletion count is determined by applying this percentage to the number of live nodes in the system. The resultant number is the number of blocks from the deletion list chosen for proper invalidation over a single heartbeat of a single DN. Value should be a positive, non-zero percentage in float notation (X.Yf), with 1.0f meaning 100%.

property.name: dfs.namenode.replication.work.multiplier.per.iteration
property.description: *Note*: Advanced property. Change with caution. This determines the total amount of block transfers to begin in parallel at a DN, for replication, when such a command list is being sent over a DN heartbeat by the NN. The actual number is obtained by multiplying this multiplier with the total number of live nodes in the cluster. The result number is the number of blocks to begin transfers immediately for, per DN heartbeat. This number can be any positive, non-zero integer.

property.name: dfs.webhdfs.enabled
property.description: Enable WebHDFS (REST API) in Namenodes and Datanodes.

property.name: hadoop.fuse.connection.timeout
property.description: The minimum number of seconds that we'll cache libhdfs connection objects in fuse_dfs. Lower values will result in lower memory consumption; higher values may speed up access by avoiding the overhead of creating new connection objects.

property.name: hadoop.fuse.timer.period
property.description: The number of seconds between cache expiry checks in fuse_dfs. Lower values will result in fuse_dfs noticing changes to Kerberos ticket caches more quickly.

property.name: dfs.metrics.percentiles.intervals
property.description: Comma-delimited set of integers denoting the desired rollover intervals (in seconds) for percentile latency metrics on the Namenode and Datanode. By default, percentile latency metrics are disabled.

property.name: dfs.encrypt.data.transfer
property.description: Whether or not actual block data that is read/written from/to HDFS should be encrypted on the wire. This only needs to be set on the NN and DNs, clients will deduce this automatically.

property.name: dfs.encrypt.data.transfer.algorithm
property.description: This value may be set to either "3des" or "rc4". If nothing is set, then the configured JCE default on the system is used (usually 3DES.) It is widely believed that 3DES is more cryptographically secure, but RC4 is substantially faster.

property.name: dfs.datanode.hdfs-blocks-metadata.enabled
property.description: Boolean which enables backend datanode-side support for the experimental DistributedFileSystem#getFileVBlockStorageLocations API.

property.name: dfs.client.file-block-storage-locations.num-threads
property.description: Number of threads used for making parallel RPCs in DistributedFileSystem#getFileBlockStorageLocations().

property.name: dfs.client.file-block-storage-locations.timeout
property.description: Timeout (in seconds) for the parallel RPCs made in DistributedFileSystem#getFileBlockStorageLocations().

property.name: dfs.journalnode.rpc-address
property.description: The JournalNode RPC server address and port.

property.name: dfs.journalnode.http-address
property.description: The address and port the JournalNode web UI listens on. If the port is 0 then the server will start on a free port.

property.name: dfs.namenode.audit.loggers
property.description: List of classes implementing audit loggers that will receive audit events. These should be implementations of org.apache.hadoop.hdfs.server.namenode.AuditLogger. The special value "default" can be used to reference the default audit logger, which uses the configured log system. Installing custom audit loggers may affect the performance and stability of the NameNode. Refer to the custom logger's documentation for more details.
